quote: To elevate the soul, poetry is necessary.
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: Go wisely and slowly. Those who rush stumble and fall.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Come away, O human child!To the waters and the wildWith a faery, hand in hand,For the world's more full of weeping than you can understand.
author: W.B. Yeats
reference: The Collected Poems of W.B. Yeats

quote: Given the choice between the experience of pain and nothing, I would choose pain.
author: William Faulkner

quote: You give but little when you give of your possessions.It is when you give of yourself that you truly give.
author: Kahlil Gibran

quote: Beauty is eternity gazing at itself in a mirror.But you are eternity and you are the mirror.
author: Kahlil Gibran

quote: Poetry is the rhythmical creation of beauty in words.
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: What can be explained is not poetry.
author: W.B. Yeats

quote: If we surrenderedto earth's intelligencewe could rise up rooted, like trees.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke
reference: Rilke's Book of Hours: Love Poems to God

quote: There's an old saying that applies to me: you can't lose a game if you don't play the game. (Act 1, scene 4)
author: William Shakespeare

quote: I live not in dreams but in contemplation of a reality that is perhaps the future.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke

quote: Resist much, obey little.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: I would define, in brief, the poetry of words as the rhythmical creation of beauty.
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: Like a sculptor, if necessary,carve a friend out of stone.Realize that your inner sight is blindand try to see a treasure in everyone.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: We ran as if to meet the moon.
author: Robert Frost

quote: She walks in beauty, like the nightOf cloudless climes and starry skies;And all that's best of dark and brightMeet in her aspect and her eyes...
author: George Gordon Byron

quote: To be a poet is a condition, not a profession.
author: Robert Frost

quote: The poetry of the earth is never dead.
author: John Keats

quote: I lean to you, numb as a fossil. Tell me I'm here.
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: I must create a system, or be enslaved by another man's. I will not reason and compare: my business is to create.
author: William Blake

quote: Once in a golden hour I cast to earth a seed. Up there came a flower, The people said, a weed.
author: Alfred Tennyson
reference: The Complete Works of Alfred Tennyson

quote: Every angel is terrifying.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke

quote: Truth can never be told so as to be understood and not be believed.
author: William Blake

quote: We sit and talk,quietly, with long lapses of silenceand I am aware of the streamthat has no language, coursingbeneath the quiet heaven ofyour eyeswhich has no speech
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: And so sepÃºlchred in such pomp dost lie,That kings for such a tomb would wish to die.
author: John Milton

quote: The blood jet is poetryThere is no stopping it.
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: We live in an old chaos of the sun.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: Resolve, and thou art free.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
reference: Flower-de-Luce, and the Masque of Pandora

quote: Green in nature is one thing, green in literature another. Nature and letters seem to have a natural antipathy; bring them together and they tear each other to pieces.
author: Virginia Woolf

quote: I have been happy, though in a dream.I have been happy-and I love the theme:Dreams! in their vivid colouring of lifeAs in that fleeting, shadowy, misty strife
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: And, even yet, I dare not let it languish,Dare not indulge in memoryâ€™s rapturous pain;Once drinking deep of that divinest anguish,How could I seek the empty world again?
author: Emily Brontë
reference: Poems by Currer, Ellis, and Acton Bell

quote: He drove his mind into the abyss where poetry is written.
author: George Orwell

quote: And to 'scape stormy days, I choose an everlasting night.
author: John Donne

quote: This is the city, and I am one of the citizens/Whatever interests the rest interests me
author: Walt Whitman

quote: Poetry is a deal of joy and pain and wonder, with a dash of the dictionary.
author: Kahlil Gibran

quote: Through endless night the earth whirls toward a creation unknown...
author: Henry Miller

quote: Any healthy man can go without food for two days--but not without poetry.
author: Charles Baudelaire

quote: The Moving Finger writes; and, having writ,Moves on: nor all thy Piety nor WitShall lure it back to cancel half a Line,Nor all thy Tears wash out a Word of it.
author: Omar Khayyám

quote: I bring you with reverent handsThe books of my numberless dreams.
author: W.B. Yeats

quote: Nature never did betrayThe heart that loved her.
author: William Wordsworth

quote: I remainMistress of mine own self and mine own soul
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: I am terrified by this dark thingThat sleeps in me;All day I feel its soft, feathery turnings, its malignity.
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: If you would hit the mark, you must aim a little above it;Every arrow that flies feels the attraction of earth.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: I too am not a bit tamed, I too am untranslatable, I sound my barbaric yawp over the roofs of the world.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: I felt a Cleaving in my Mind-As if my Brain had split-I tried to match it-Seam by Seam-But could not make it fit.
author: Emily Dickinson
reference: The Complete Poems of Emily Dickinson

quote: A book of verses underneath the boughA flask of wine, a loaf of bread and thouBeside me singing in the wildernessAnd wilderness is paradise now.
author: Omar Khayyám
reference: Edward Fitzgerald's The Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam

quote: The profoundest of all sensualitiesis the sense of truthand the next deepest sensual experienceis the sense of justice.
author: D.H. Lawrence

quote: Now begins to rise in me the familiar rhythm; words that have lain dormant now lift, now toss their crests, and fall and rise, and falls again. I am a poet, yes. Surely I am a great poet.
author: Virginia Woolf

quote: No man can reveal to you aught but that which already lies half asleep in the dawning of your knowledge.
author: Kahlil Gibran

quote: I found the poems in the fields,And only wrote them down.
author: John Clare
reference: The Later Poems, 1837-1864: Volumes I and II

quote: And the Spring arose on the garden fair,Like the Spirit of Love felt everywhere;And each flower and herb on Earth's dark breastRose from the dreams of its wintry rest.
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: so much dependsupona red wheelbarrowglazed with rainwaterbeside the whitechickens.
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: Soul receives from soul that knowledge, therefore not by book nor from tongue. If knowledge of mysteries come after emptiness of mind, that is illumination of heart.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: All days are nights to see till I see thee, And nights bright days when dreams do show thee me.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: We talk so abstractly about poetry because all of us are usually bad poets.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: A FEATHER.A feather is trimmed, it is trimmed by the light and the bug and the post, it is trimmed by little leaning and by all sorts of mounted reserves and loud volumes. It is surely cohesive.
author: Gertrude Stein

quote: Someday you will name me, then gently place those burning holy roses in my hair.[Songs of Longing]
author: Rainer Maria Rilke
reference: Rainer Maria Rilke - SÃ¤mtliche Werke  (Complete Works)

quote: Works of art are of an infinite solitude, and no means of approach is so useless as criticism. Only love can touch and hold them and be fair to them.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke

quote: It's better to swim in the sea belowThan to swing in the air and feed the crow,Says jolly Ned Teach of Bristol.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: Poetry is an abstraction bloodied.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: Water, water, everywhere,And all the boards did shrink;Water, water, everywhere,Nor any drop to drink.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
reference: The Rime of the Ancient Mariner

quote: A wounded dear leaps the highest
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: Sir, I admit your general rule, That every poet is a fool, But you yourself may serve to show it, That every fool is not a poet.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: Pity me that the heart is slow to learnWhat the swift mind beholds at every turn.
author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

quote: When you are old and grey and full of sleep  And nodding by the fire, take down this book,  And slowly read, and dream of the soft look Your eyes had once, and of their shadows deep
author: W.B. Yeats
reference: The Collected Poems of W.B. Yeats

quote: ..."vers libre," (free verse) or nine-tenths of it, is not a new metre any more than sleeping in a ditch is a new school of architecture.
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: Since then, at an uncertain hour, That agony returns: And till my ghastly tale is told, This heart within me burns.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
reference: The Rime of the Ancient Mariner

quote: If it ain't a pleasure, it ain't a poem.
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: In Xanadu did Kubla KhanA stately pleasure-dome decree:Where Alph, the sacred river, ranThrough caverns measureless to man Down to a sunless sea.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: What would the world be, once bereft Of wet and of wildness? Let them be left, O let them be left, wildness and wet; Long live the weeds and the wilderness yet.
author: Gerard Manley Hopkins
reference: Gerard Manley Hopkins: The Complete Poems

quote: I sent my Soul through the Invisible, Some letter of that After-life to spell: And by and by my Soul return'd to me, And answer'd: 'I Myself am Heav'n and Hell
author: Omar Khayyám

quote: Beauties in vain their pretty eyes may roll; Charms strike the sight, but merit wins the soul.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: When from our better selves we have too longBeen parted by the hurrying world, and droop,Sick of its business, of its pleasures tired,How gracious, how benign, is Solitude
author: William Wordsworth

quote: Unasked, Unsought, Love gives itself but is not bought
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
reference: The Complete Works of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: The poet doesn't invent. He listens.
author: Jean Cocteau

quote: One merit of poetry few persons will deny: it says more and in fewer words than prose.
author: Voltaire

quote: I am solitary as grass. What is it I miss?Shall I ever find it, whatever it is?
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: Whatever the imagination seizes as Beauty must be truth -whether it existed before or not
author: John Keats

quote: Out beyond ideas of wrongdoing and rightdoing there is a field.I'll meet you there.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: Was not writing poetry a secret transaction, a voice answering a voice?
author: Virginia Woolf

quote: The difference between the poet and the mathematician is that the poet tries to get his head into the heavens while the mathematician tries to get the heavens into his head.
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: Poetry and art and knowledge are sacred and pure.
author: George Eliot

quote: Your thighs are appletrees. Your knees are a southern breeze.
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: It is at the edge of the petal that love waits
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: Blood was its Avatar and its seal.
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: To SorrowI bade good morrow,And thought to leave her far away behind;But cheerly, cheerly,She loves me dearly;She is so constant to me, and so kind.
author: John Keats

quote: To see a World in a grain of sand,And a Heaven in a wild flower,Hold Infinity in the palm of your hand,And Eternity in an hour.
author: William Blake

quote: My friend, you thought you lost Him;that all your life you've been separated from Him.Filled with wonder, you've always looked outside for Him,and haven't searched within your own house.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: My brain hums with scraps of poetry and madness.
author: Virginia Woolf

quote: Wake! For the Sun, who scatter'd into flightThe Stars before him from the Field of Night,Drives Night along with them from Heav'n,and strikesThe Sultan's Turret with a Shaft of Light
author: Omar Khayyám

quote: One need not be a Chamber - to be Haunted - One need not be a House - The Brain has Corridors - surpassing Material Place -
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: When soul meets soul on lovers' lips.
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: I celebrate myself, and sing myself, And what I assume you shall assume,For every atom belonging to me as good belongs to you.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: And must I then, indeed, Pain, live with youall through my life?-sharing my fire, my bed,Sharing-oh, worst of all things!-the same head?-And, when I feed myself, feeding you too?
author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

quote: O words are poor receipts for what time hath stole away
author: John Clare

quote: Love's mysteries in souls do grow,But yet the body is his book.
author: John Donne

quote: This is the Hour of Lead â€“ Remembered, if outlived, As Freezing persons, recollect the Snow â€“ First â€“ Chill â€“ then Stupor â€“ then the letting go â€“
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: To me, fair friend, you never can be old,For as you were when first your eye I ey'd, Such seems your beauty still.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Love is the poetry of the senses!
author: Honoré de Balzac

quote: If our two loves be one, or, thou and I Love so alike, that none do slacken, none can die.
author: John Donne

quote: The eye--it cannot choose but see;We cannot bid the ear be still;Our bodies feel, where'er they be,Against or with our will.
author: William Wordsworth

quote: Everything in creation has its appointed painter or poet and remains in bondage like the princess in the fairy tale 'til its appropriate liberator comes to set it free.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Dear to me is sleep: still more, being made of stone,While pain and guilt still linger here below,Blindness and numbness--these please me alone;Then do not wake me, keep your voices low.
author: Michelangelo Buonarroti

quote: I do not know which to prefer,The beauty of inflectionsOr the beauty of innuendosThe blackbird whistlingOr just after.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: Poets are shameless with their experiences: they exploit them.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: No one but Night, with tears on her dark face, watches beside me in this windy place.
author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

quote: A billion stars go spinning through the night,glittering above your head,But in you is the presence that will bewhen all the stars are dead.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke
reference: The Selected Poetry of Rainer Maria Rilke

quote: Our state cannot be severed, we are one,One flesh; to lose thee were to lose myself.
author: John Milton

quote: The only emperor is the emperor of ice cream.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: There's a certain slant of light,On winter afternoons,That oppresses, like the weightOf cathedral tunes.
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: Lord, may the pain be ours, And the weakness that it brings, But at least give us the strength, Of not showing it to anyone!
author: Fernando Pessoa

quote: I will come back to you, I swear I will;And you will know me still.I shall be only a little tallerThan when I went.
author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

quote: Inebriate of Air - am I -And Debauchee of Dew -Reeling - thro endless summer days -From Inns of Molten Blue -
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: If I am more alive because love burns and chars me,as a fire, given wood or wind, feels new elation,it's that he who lays me low is my salvation,and invigorates the more, the more he scars me.
author: Michelangelo Buonarroti

quote: Dreams, books, are each a world; and books, we know,Are a substantial world, both pure and good:Round these, with tendrils strong as flesh and blood,Our pastime and our happiness will grow.
author: William Wordsworth

quote: Every word was once a poem.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: I am inhabited by a cry. Nightly it flaps outLooking, with its hooks, for something to love.
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: Love is a shadow. How you lie and cry after it
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: Poetry: the best words in the best order.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: You dance inside my chest,where no one sees you,but sometimes I do, and thatsight becomes this art.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: You lethargic, waiting upon me,waiting for the fire and Iattendant upon you, shaken by your beautyShaken by your beauty Shaken.
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: The last thing one discovers in composing a work is what to put first.
author: Blaise Pascal

quote: All bad poetry springs from genuine feeling. To be natural is to be obvious, and to be obvious is to be inartistic.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: O love, how did you get here?--Nick and the Candlestick
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: Stars open among the lilies.Are you not blinded by such expressionless sirens?This is the silence of astounded souls.
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: I would not come in.I meant not even if asked,And I hadn't been.
author: Robert Frost

quote: The lamb misused breeds public strifeAnd yet forgives the butcher's knife.
author: William Blake

quote: It is strange how a scrap of poetry works in the mind and makes the legs move in time to it along the road.
author: Virginia Woolf

quote: How dull it is to pause, to make an end,To rust unburnishâ€™d, not to shine in use!As thoâ€™ to breathe were life!
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: A lover goes toward his beloved as enthusiastically as a schoolboy leaving his books, but when he leaves his girlfriend, he feels as miserable as the schoolboy on his way to school. (Act 2, scene 2)
author: William Shakespeare

quote: A precious, mouldering pleasure â€™t is To meet an antique book, In just the dress his century wore; A privilege, I think.
author: Emily Dickinson
reference: The Complete Poems of Emily Dickinson

quote: We, all who live, haveA life that is livedAnd another life that is thought,And the only life we haveIt's the one that is dividedIn right or wrong.
author: Fernando Pessoa

quote: For we cannot tarry here,We must march my darlings, we must bear the brunt of danger,We, the youthful sinewy races, all the rest on us depend, Pioneers! O pioneers!
author: Walt Whitman

quote: Ye are better than all the balladsThat ever were sung or said;For ye are living poems,And all the rest are dead.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: I do think the barsThat kept my spirit in are burst - that IAm sailing with thee through the dizzy sky!How beautiful thou art!
author: John Keats

quote: A song is the exultation of the mind dwelling on eternal things, bursting forth in the voice.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: The press of my foot to the earth springs a hundred affections,They scorn the best I can do to relate them.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: I will soothe you and heal you,I will bring you roses.I too have been covered with thorns.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: This poetry. I never know what I'm going to say.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: So runs my dream, but what am I?An infant crying in the nightAn infant crying for the lightAnd with no language but a cry.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Licence my roving hands, and let them go Before, behind, between, above, below.
author: John Donne

quote: I live not in myself, but I becomePortion of that around me: and to meHigh mountains are a feeling, but the humof human cities torture.
author: George Gordon Byron

quote: Is it the sea you hear in me,Its dissatisfactions?Or the voice of nothing, that was you madness?
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: Where the bright seraphim in burning rowTheir loud uplifted angel trumpets blow.
author: John Milton

quote: Poetry makes life what lights and music do the stage.
author: Charles Dickens

quote: I arise from dreams of thee,And a spirit in my feetHas led me- who knows how?To thy chamber-window, Sweet!
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: For I have learned to look on nature, not as in the hour of thoughtless youth; but hearing oftentimes the still, sad music of humanity.
author: William Wordsworth
reference: Lines Composed a Few Miles Above Tintern Abbey

quote: The young student sits with his head bent over his books, and his mind straying in youth's dreamland; where prose is prowling on the desk and poetry hiding in the heart.
author: Rabindranath Tagore

quote: A bank is a place where they lend you an umbrella in fair weather and ask for it back when it begins to rain.
author: Robert Frost

quote: Alone, alone, all, all alone, Alone on a wide wide sea! And never a saint took pity on My soul in agony.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
reference: The Rime of the Ancient Mariner

quote: Writing, then, was a substitute for myself: if you don't love me, love my writing & love me for my writing. It is also much more: a way of ordering and reordering the chaos of experience.
author: Sylvia Plath
reference: The Unabridged Journals of Sylvia Plath

quote: If poetry comes not as naturally as the leaves to a tree it had better not come at all.
author: John Keats

quote: What wretched poverty of language! To compare stars to diamonds!
author: Gustave Flaubert
reference: Flaubert in Egypt: A Sensibility on Tour

quote: Art is long, and Time is fleeting.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: One must read poetry with one's nerves.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: If you want me again look for me under your boot soles.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: Some people will tell you there is a great deal of poetry and fine sentiment in a chest of tea.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Such sweet compulsion doth in music lie.
author: John Milton

quote: I act as the tongue of you,... tied in your mouth . . . . in mine it begins to be loosened.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: Poetry is the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings: it takes its origin from emotion recollected in tranquility.
author: William Wordsworth

quote: A little learning is a dangerous thing.Drink deep, or taste not the Pierian Spring;There shallow draughts intoxicate the brain,and drinking largely sobers us again.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: I know that I shall meet my fate somewhere among the clouds above; those that I fight I do not hate, those that I guard I do not love.
author: W.B. Yeats

quote: Some men are born sodomites, some achieve sodomy, and some have sodomy thrust upon them...
author: Aleister Crowley
reference: The Scented Garden Of Abdullah The Satirist Of Shiraz

quote: Under the greenwood tree,Who loves to lie with meAnd tune his merry note,Unto the sweet bird's throat;Come hither, come hither, come hither.Here shall he seeNo enemyBut winter and rough weather.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: A mighty flame follows a tiny spark.
author: Dante Alighieri

quote: Poetry is a mirror which makes beautiful that which is distorted
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: This poetry. I never know what I'm going to say.I don't plan it.When I'm outside the saying of it,I get very quiet and rarely speak at all.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: True and false fears let us refrain, Let us love nobly, and live, and add again Years and years unto years, till we attain To write threescore: this is the second of our reign.
author: John Donne

quote: One! two! and through and throughThe vorpal blade went snickersnack!He left it dead, and with its headHe went galumphing back.
author: Lewis Carroll
reference: Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There

quote: I wish I was either in your arms full of faith, or that a Thunder bolt would strike me.
author: John Keats
reference: Bright Star: Love Letters and Poems of John Keats to Fanny Brawne

quote: The exceeding brightness of this early sunMakes me conceive how dark I have become.
author: Wallace Stevens
reference: The Palm at the End of the Mind: Selected Poems and a Play

quote: The poem must resist the intelligenceAlmost successfully.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: To wake the soul by tender strokes of art,To raise the genius, and to mend the heart
author: Alexander Pope

quote: But writing poems and letters doesn't seem to do much good.
author: Sylvia Plath
reference: The Unabridged Journals of Sylvia Plath

quote: For I dipped into the future, far as human eye could see,Saw the Vision of the world, and all the wonder that would be.
author: Alfred Tennyson
reference: The Complete Works of Alfred Tennyson

quote: If Galileo had said in verse that the world moved, the inquisition might have let him alone.
author: Thomas Hardy

quote: Art too is just a way of living.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke

quote: A poem is never a put-up job, so to speak. It begins as a lump in the throat, a sense of wrong, a homesickness, a lovesickness. It is never a thought to begin with.
author: Robert Frost

quote: Conceptions are artificial. Perceptions are essential.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: Catch from the board of beauty/ Such careless crumbs as fall.
author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

quote: Then all the charm Is broken--all that phantom-world so fair Vanishes, and a thousand circlets spread, And each mis-shape the other.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: we want it visible	to showwhen even the most 	visible joy		will reveal itselfonly when we have		transformed it within.thereâ€™s nowhere, my love, the world can existexpect within.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke

quote: How can the bird that is born for joySit in a cage and sing?How can a child, when fears annoy,But droop his tender wing,And forget his youthful spring?
author: William Blake
reference: Songs of Innocence and of Experience

quote: Only times and places, only names and ghosts.
author: Aldous Huxley

quote: Breath, dreams, silence, invincible calm, you triumph.
author: Paul Valéry

quote: There will never be an endTo this droning of the surf.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: The moon is no door. It is a face in its own right,White as a knuckle and terribly upset.It drags the sea after it like a dark crime; it is quietWith the O-gape of complete despair. I live here.
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: Ah! well a-day! what evil looks Had I from old and young! Instead of the cross, the Albatross About my neck was hung.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
reference: The Rime of the Ancient Mariner

quote: Then others for breath of words respect,Me for my dumb thoughts, speaking in effect.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: I sleep with thee, and wake with thee,And yet thou are not there;I fill my arms with thoughts of thee,And press the common air.
author: John Clare
reference: The Later Poems, 1837-1864: Volumes I and II

quote: Remembrance and reflection how allied!What thin partitions Sense from Thought divide!
author: Alexander Pope
reference: Essay on Man and Other Poems

quote: Verses which do not teach men new and moving truths do not deserve to be read.
author: Voltaire

quote: I had a dove and the sweet dove died; And I have thought it died of grieving: O, what could it grieve for? Its feet were tied, With a silken thread of my own hand's weaving.
author: John Keats

quote: Some who grow dull religious straight commenceAnd gain in morals what they lose in sense.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: Every particle of dust on a patch of earthWas a sun-cheek or brow of the morning star;Shake the dust off your sleeve carefully--That too was a delicate, fair face.
author: Omar Khayyám

quote: And I or you pocketless of a dime, may purchase the pick of the earth.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: I sometimes think you despise poetry,' said Phineas. 'When it is false I do. The difficulty is to know when it is false and when it is true.
author: Anthony Trollope

quote: To be loved is all I need, And whom I love, I love indeed.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: Mon Dieu, la vie est par trop moche.
author: Aldous Huxley

quote: If rape or arson, poison or the knifeHas wove no pleasing patterns in the stuffOf this drab canvas we accept as life -It is because we are not bold enough!
author: Charles Baudelaire

quote: I placed a jar in Tennessee and round it was upon a hill.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: One impulse from a vernal wood May teach you more of man, Of moral evil and of good, Than all the sages can.
author: William Wordsworth

quote: The poet knows that he speaks adequately, then, only when he speaks somewhat wildly.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Language has not the power to speak what love inditesThe soul lies buried in the Ink that writes
author: John Clare
reference: The Later Poems, 1837-1864: Volumes I and II

quote: The way through the worldIs more difficult to find than the way beyond it.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: Has it ever occurred to you,' he said, 'that the whole history of English poetry has been de-termined by the fact that the English language lacks rhymes?
author: George Orwell

quote: But to go to school in a summer morn,O! It drives all joy away;Under a cruel eye outworn,The little ones spend the dayIn sighing and dismay.
author: William Blake

quote: Open wide the mind's cage-door,She'll dart forth, and cloudward soar.
author: John Keats

quote: Pensar incomoda como andar Ã  chuvaQuando o vento cresce e parece que chove mais.
author: Alberto Caeiro

quote: The business of love is cruelty which,by our wills, we transform to live together.
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: If I feel physically as if the top of my head were taken off, I know that is poetry.
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: The muffled syllables that Nature speaksFill us with deeper longing for her word; She hides a meaning that the spirit seeks,She makes a sweeter music than is heard.
author: George Santayana

quote: And this gray spirit yearning in desireTo follow knowledge like a sinking star,Beyond the utmost bound of human thought.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Bright star, would I were steadfast as thou art--Not in lone splendour hung aloft the nightAnd watching, with eternal lids apart,Like nature's patient, sleepless Eremite.
author: John Keats

quote: I've given offense by saying I'd as soon write free verse as play tennis with the net down.
author: Robert Frost

quote: Crowded places, I shunned them as noises too rudeAnd fled to the silence of sweet solitude.
author: John Clare

quote: Pensive they sit, and roll their languid eyes.
author: John Keats

quote: A pear should come to the table popped with juice,Ripened in warmth and served in warmth. On termsLike these, autumn beguiles the fatalist.
author: Wallace Stevens
reference: The Palm at the End of the Mind: Selected Poems and a Play

quote: O Stunden in der Kindheit,da hinter den Figuren mehr als nurVergangnes war und vor uns nicht die Zukunft.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke

quote: Don't you just love poetry that gives you a crinkly feeling up and down your back?
author: L.M. Montgomery

quote: Il Ã©tait tard; ainsi qu'une mÃ©daille neuveLa pleine lune s'Ã©talait,Et la solennitÃ© de la nuit, comme un fleuveSur Paris dormant ruisselait.
author: Charles Baudelaire

quote: As a poet and as a mathematician, he would reason well; as a mere mathematician, he could not have reasoned at all.
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: I love my love with a b because she is peculiar.
author: Gertrude Stein
reference: Narration: Four Lectures by Gertrude Stein

quote: Every poet... finds himself born in the midst of prose. He has to struggle from the littleness and obstruction of an actual world into the freedom and infinitude of an ideal.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Straight between them ran the pathway,Never grew the grass upon it
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: For the beginning is assuredlythe end- since we know nothing, pureand simple, beyondour own complexities.
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: I heard a bird congratulating itselfall day for being a jay.Nobody cared. But it was gladall over again, and said so, again.
author: William Stafford

quote: Let Him easter in us, be a dayspring to the dimness of us, be a crimson-cresseted east.
author: Gerard Manley Hopkins

quote: A wealth you cannot imagineflows through you.Do not consider what strangers say.Be secluded in your secret heart-house,that bowl of silence.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: Oh, friend, forget not, when you fain would noteIn me a beauty that was never mine,How first you knew me in a book I wrote,How first you loved me for a written line....
author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

quote: How can I find the words? Poets have taken them all and left me with nothing to say or do"Except to teach me for the first time what they meant.
author: Dorothy L. Sayers

quote: Even the moon is only poetical because there is a man in the moon.
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: Poetry is the scholar's art.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: Isn't joyful or painful this pain in which I rejoice
author: Fernando Pessoa

quote: A writer is not so much someone who has something to say as he is someone who has found a process that will bring about new things he would not have thought of if he had not started to say them.
author: William Stafford

quote: I said: 'A line will take us hours maybe;Yet if it does not seem a moment's thought,Our stitching and unstitching has been naught.
author: W.B. Yeats

quote: I have no words - alas! - to tellThe loveliness of loving well!
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: beautyâ€™ is related not to â€˜lovelinessâ€™ but to a state in which reality plays a part.
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: Here the frailest leaves of me and yet my strongest lasting, Here I shade and hide my thoughts, I myself do not expose them, And yet they expose me more than all my other poems
author: Walt Whitman

quote: How far away the stars seem, and how farIs our first kiss, and ah, how old my heart!
author: W.B. Yeats
reference: The Collected Poems of W.B. Yeats

quote: I dreamed that you bewitched me into bedAnd sung me moon-struck, kissed me quite insane.(I think I made you up inside my head.)
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: To see the Summer SkyIs Poetry, though never in a Book it lie-True Poems flee-
author: Emily Dickinson
reference: The Complete Poems of Emily Dickinson

quote: Not in the clamor of the crowded street,Not in the shouts and plaudits of the throng,But in ourselves, are triumph and defeat.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: Much Madness is Divinest Sense, to a Discerning Eye....
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: O, how this spring of love resemblethThe uncertain glory of an April day,Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,And by and by a cloud takes all away!
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Kiss me, so long but as a kiss may last!
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: Music, when combined with a pleasurable idea, is poetry; music, without the idea, is simply music; the idea, without the music, is prose, from its very definitiveness.
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: Again I see you, But me I don't see!, The magical mirror in which I saw myself has been broken, And only a piece of me I see in each fatal fragment - Only a piece of you and me!...
author: Fernando Pessoa

quote: Language is fossil Poetry.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: I have been used to consider poetry as the food of love
author: Jane Austen

quote: All that we call sacred history attests that the birth of a poet is the principal event in chronology.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: I spit into the face of Time That has transfigured me.
author: W.B. Yeats

quote: In scientific thinking are always present elements of poetry. Science and music requires a thought homogeneous.
author: Albert Einstein

quote: Why are there trees I never walk under but large and melodious thoughts descend upon me?
author: Walt Whitman

quote: I came here to be for all and with all,and what I do today in my solitudewill be echoed tomorrow by the multitude.What I say now with one heartwill be said tomorrow by thousands of hearts...
author: Kahlil Gibran

quote: Let be be finale of seem.The only emperor is the emperor of ice-cream.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: A poem is a meteor.
author: Wallace Stevens

quote: L'aube exalteÃ© ainsi qu'un peuple de colombes, et j'ai vu quelquefois ce que l'homme a cru voir!(And dawn, exalted like a host of doves - and then I've seen what men believe they've seen!)
author: Arthur Rimbaud

quote: With slouch and swing around the ringWe trod the Foolsâ€™ Parade!We did not care: we knew we wereThe Devilsâ€™ Own Brigade:And shaven head and feet of leadMake a merry masquerade.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: Ideas must work through the brains and arms of men, or they are no better than dreams
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Here with a Loaf of Bread beneath the Bough,A Flask of Wine, a Book of Verse - and ThouBeside me singing in the Wilderness -And Wilderness is Paradise enow.
author: Omar Khayyám

quote: Poetry should be great and unobtrusive, a thing which enters into one's soul, and does not startle it or amaze it with itself, but with its subject.
author: John Keats

quote: When the green woods laugh with the voice of joy, And the dimpling stream runs laughing by; When the air does laugh with our merry wit, And the green hill laughs with the noise of it.
author: George Gordon Byron

quote: After the leaves have fallen, we returnTo a plain sense of things. It is as ifWe had come to an end of the imagination,Inanimate in an inert savoir.
author: Wallace Stevens
reference: The Palm at the End of the Mind: Selected Poems and a Play

quote: Only our love hath no decay; This no tomorrow hath, nor yesterday, Running it never runs from us away, But truly keeps his first, last, everlasting day.
author: John Donne

quote: The mimicry of passion is the most intolerable of all poses.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: â€¦wisely mingled poetry and prose.
author: Louisa May Alcott

quote: I give you the end of a golden string,Only wind it into a ball,It will lead you in at Heaven's gateBuilt in Jerusalem's wall.
author: William Blake

quote: Yes, I am proud; I must be proud to seeMen not afraid of God afraid of me.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: I have been driven many times upon my knees by the overwhelming conviction that I had no where else to go. My own wisdom and that of all about me seemed insufficient for that day.
author: Abraham Lincoln

quote: Faith is not something to grasp, it is a state to grow into.
author: Mahatma Gandhi

quote: It is difficult to make a man miserable while he feels worthy of himself and claims kindred to the great God who made him.
author: Abraham Lincoln

quote: You have as much laughter as you have faith.
author: Martin Luther

quote: Matched with an aged wife, I mete and doleUnequal laws unto a savage race,That hoard, and sleep, and feed, and know not me.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: The world and the friends that lived in it are shadows: you alone remain real in this drowsing room.
author: Aldous Huxley

quote: Two such as you with such a master speedCannot be parted nor be swept awayFrom one another once you are agreedThat life is only life forevermoreTogether wing to wing and oar to oar
author: Robert Frost

quote: They miss the whisper that runsany day in your mind,"Who are you really, wanderer?--and the answer you have to giveno matter how dark and coldthe world around you is:"Maybe I'm a king.
author: William Stafford

quote: You must not lose faith in humanity. Humanity is like an ocean; if a few drops of the ocean are dirty, the ocean does not become dirty.
author: Mahatma Gandhi

quote: There lives more faith in honest doubt, believe me, than in half the creeds.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: I had to deny knowledge in order to make room for faith.
author: Immanuel Kant

quote: All things are inconstant except the faith in the soul, which changes all things and fills their inconstancy with light.
author: James Joyce

quote: Leap, and the net will appear.
author: Julia Cameron

quote: If merely 'feeling good' could decide, drunkenness would be the supremely valid human experience.
author: William James

quote: Back of every creation, supporting it like an arch, is faith. Enthusiasm is nothing: It comes and goes. But if one believes, then miracles occur.
author: Henry Miller

quote: The closer one approaches to God, the simpler one becomes.
author: Teresa of Ávila

quote: Faith is like love: it does not let itself be forced.
author: Arthur Schopenhauer

quote: Hill tops like hot iron glitter bright in the sun, And the rivers we're eying burn to gold as they run; Burning hot is the ground, liquid gold is the air; Whoever looks round sees Eternity there.
author: John Clare

quote: Music resembles poetry, in eachAre nameless graces which no methods teach,And which a master hand alone can reach.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: Success is counted sweetest by those ne'er succeed.
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: Where Alph, the sacred river, ran Through caverns measureless to man Down to a sunless sea.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: Stasis in darkness.Then the substanceless blue
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: I have no life but this, To lead it here; Nor any death, but lest Dispelled from there; Nor tie to earths to come, Nor action new, Except through this extent, The realm of you.
author: Emily Dickinson
reference: The Complete Poems of Emily Dickinson

quote: I fain would follow love, if that could be; I needs must follow death, who calls for me; Call and I follow, I follow! let me die.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Think of your woods and orchards without birds!Of empty nests that cling to boughs and beamsAs in an idiot's brain remembered wordsHang empty 'mid the cobwebs of his dreams!
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: I believe in intuitions and inspirations...I sometimes FEEL that I am right. I do not KNOW that I am.
author: Albert Einstein

quote: You can't know, you can only believe - or not.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: Faith, in the sense in which I am here using the word, is the art of holding on to things your reason has once accepted, in spite of your changing moods.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: What looks like politics, and imagines itself to be political, will one day unmask itself as a religious movement.
author: Søren Kierkegaard

quote: O the mind, mind has mountains; cliffs of fallFrightful, sheer, no-man-fathomed.
author: Gerard Manley Hopkins

quote: The still watersWrap my lips,Eyes, nose and ears,A clearCellophane I cannot crack.
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: Next o'er his books his eyes began to roll,In pleasing memory of all he stole.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: The same that oft-times hath charm'd magic casements, opening on the foam of perilous seas, in fairy lands forlorn.
author: John Keats

quote: EpitaphDen Tigern ertrann ichDie Wanzen nÃ¤hrte ichAufgefressen wurde ichVon den MittelmÃ¤ÃŸigkeiten.
author: Bertolt Brecht

quote: All I have seen teaches me to trust the Creator for all I have not seen.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Faith consists in believing what reason cannot.
author: Voltaire

quote: Care more for a grain of faith than a ton of excitement.
author: Charles Haddon Spurgeon

quote: Faith is a fine inventionWhen gentlemen can see,But microscopes are prudentIn an emergency.
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: Believe to the end, even if all men went astray and you were left the only one faithful; bring your offering even then and praise God in your loneliness.
author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

quote: The majority of my patients consisted not of believers but of those who had lost their faith.
author: C.G. Jung

quote: If you don't know the kind of person I amand I don't know the kind of person you area pattern that others made may prevail in the worldand following the wrong god home we may miss our star.
author: William Stafford
reference: The Way It Is: New and Selected Poems

quote: Literature is not a picture of life, but is a separate experience with its own kind of flow and enhancement.
author: William Stafford

quote: Poetry must be as new as foam, and as old as the rock.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: O I never thought that joys would run away from boys,Or that boys would change their minds and forsake such summer joys;But alack I never dreamed that the world had other toys
author: John Clare

quote: Thou, silent form, dost tease us out of thoughtAs doth eternity...
author: John Keats
reference: Ode on a Grecian Urn and Other Poems

quote: From morn to noon he fell, from noon to dewy eve, a summer's day; and with the setting sun dropped from the zenith like a falling star.
author: John Milton

quote: I am afraid that the schools will prove the very gates of hell, unless they diligently labor in explaining the Holy Scriptures and engraving them in the heart of the youth.
author: Martin Luther

quote: All who call on God in true faith, earnestly from the heart, will certainly be heard, and will receive what they have asked and desired.
author: Martin Luther

quote: What is a woman that you forsake herAnd the hearth fire and the home acreTo go with that old grey widow-maker?
author: Rudyard Kipling

quote: . . . On a sandbarsunlight stretches out its limbs, or is ita sycamore, so brazen, so clean and bold?
author: William Stafford

quote: I believe in Christianity as I believe that the sun has risen: not only because I see it, but because by it I see everything else.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: A casual stroll through the lunatic asylum shows that faith does not prove anything.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Doubt everything. Find your own light.
author: Gautama Buddha

quote: Even the merest gesture is holy if it is filled with faith.
author: Franz Kafka

quote: It would be the height of absurdity to label ignorance tempered by humility "faith"!(Institutio III.2.3)
author: John Calvin

quote: As when, O lady mine,With chiselled touchThe stone unhewn and coldBecomes a living mould,The more the marble wastes,The more the statue grows.
author: Michelangelo Buonarroti

quote: An orphan's curse would drag to hell A spirit from on high; But oh! more horrible than that Is the curse in a dead man's eye! Seven days, seven nights, I saw that curse, And yet I could not die.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
reference: The Rime of the Ancient Mariner

quote: A fool lies here who tried to hustle the East.
author: Rudyard Kipling

quote: I live my life in growing orbits which move out over the things of the world.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke

quote: No one can usurp the heights...But those to whom the miseries of the worldAre misery, and will not let them rest.
author: John Keats

quote: The poet is the sayer, the namer, and represents beauty.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Ah! The anguish, the vile rage, the despairOf not being able to expressWith a shout, an extreme and bitter shout,The bleeding of my heart.
author: Fernando Pessoa
reference: A Little Larger Than the Entire Universe: Selected Poems

quote: No sword Of wrath her right arm whirl'd,But one poor poet's scroll, and with his word She shook the world.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: To one who has faith, no explanation is necessary. To one without faith, no explanation is possible.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Faith and love are apt to be spasmodic in the best minds. Men live the brink of mysteries and harmonies into which they never enter, and with their hands on the door-latch they die outside.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: True wisdom consists in two things: Knowledge of God and Knowledge of Self.
author: John Calvin

quote: I must confess that I lost faith in the sanity of the world
author: H.G. Wells

quote: To believe that what has not occurred in history will not occur at all, is to argue disbelief in the dignity of man.
author: Mahatma Gandhi

quote: Confidence in others' honesty is no light testimony of one's own integrity.
author: Michel de Montaigne

quote: A savage place! as holy and enchanted As e'er beneath a waning moon was haunted By woman wailing for her demon-lover!
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: I take thee at thy word:Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized;Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: I want to unfold.I donâ€™t want to be folded anywhere,because where I am folded,there I am a lie.
author: Rainer Maria Rilke
reference: Rilke's Book of Hours: Love Poems to God

quote: brave love, dreamnot of staunching such strict flame, but come,lean to my wound; burn on, burn on.
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: I know now, Lord, why you utter no answer. You are yourself the answer. Before your face questions die away. What other answer would suffice?
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: Faith is an oasis in the heart which will never be reached by the caravan of thinking.
author: Kahlil Gibran

quote: At times one remains faithful to a cause only because its opponents do not cease to be insipid.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Faith is a knowledge within the heart, beyond the reach of proof.
author: Kahlil Gibran

quote: When you see no present advantage, walk by faith and not by sight. Do God the honor to trust Him when it comes to matters of loss for the sake of principle.
author: Charles Haddon Spurgeon

quote: The life of faith is not a life of mounting up with wings, but a life of walking and not fainting.
author: Oswald Chambers
reference: My Utmost for His Highest: Selections for the Year

quote: Each of us has an inner dream that we can unfold if we will just have the courage to admit what it is. And the faith to trust our own admission. The admitting is often very difficult.
author: Julia Cameron

quote: Faith is stronger than so-called reason.
author: Hermann Hesse

quote: Dignity, and even holiness too, sometimes, are more questions of coat and waistcoat than some people imagine.
author: Charles Dickens

quote: When I think of the Crucifixion, I commit the sin of envy.
author: Simone Weil

quote: Belief creates the actual fact.
author: William James

quote: There are many faiths, but the spirit is one - in me, and in you, and in him. So that if everyone believes himself, all will be united; everyone be himself and all will be as one.
author: Leo Tolstoy

quote: It is not as a child that I believe and confess Jesus Christ. My hosanna is born of a furnace of doubt.
author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

quote: If the Sun and Moon should ever doubt, they'd immediately go out.
author: William Blake

quote: For if there's no everlasting God, there's no such thing as virtue, and there's no need of it.
author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

quote: The Christian should work as if all depended upon him, and pray as if it all depended upon God.
author: Charles Haddon Spurgeon

quote: Un sceptique qui adhÃ¨re Ã  un croyant cela est simple comme la loi des couleurs complÃ©mentaires.Ce qui nous manque nous attire.
author: Victor Hugo

quote: As to the doubt of the soul I discover it to be false: a mood not a conclusion. My conclusion is the Faith. Corporate, organized, a personality, teaching. A thing, not a theory. It.
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: It is not great faith but true faith that saves. And the salvation lies not in the faith but in the Christ in whom faith trusts.
author: Charles Haddon Spurgeon

quote: Always carry champagne! In victory You deserve it & in defeat You need it!
author: Napoléon Bonaparte

quote: Faith is the highest passion in a human being. Many in everygeneration may not come that far, but none comes further.
author: Søren Kierkegaard

quote: We pray for the big things and forget to give thanks for the ordinary, small (and yet really not small) gifts.
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer
reference: Life Together: The Classic Exploration of Christian Community

quote: to have faith is precisely to lose one's mind so as to win God.
author: Søren Kierkegaard
reference: The Sickness Unto Death: A Christian Psychological Exposition for Upbuilding and Awakening

quote: Every tomorrow has two handles. We can take hold of it with the handle of anxiety or the handle of faith.
author: Henry Ward Beecher

quote: By denying scientific principles, one may maintain any paradox.
author: Galileo Galilei

quote: Instead of giving a firm foundation for setting the conscience of man at rest forever, Thou didst choose all that is exceptional, vague and enigmatic.
author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

quote: Have faith in the Yankees my son. Think of the great DiMaggio.
author: Ernest Hemingway
reference: The Old Man and the Sea

quote: He is cured by faith who is sick of fate.
author: James Joyce

quote: To make a man a saint, it must indeed be by grace; and whoever doubts this does not know what a saint is, or a man.
author: Blaise Pascal

quote: As a general rule, Providence seldom vouchsafes to mortals any more than just that degree of encouragement which suffices to keep them at a reasonably full exertion of their powers.
author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
reference: The House of the Seven Gables

quote: knowledge, absolutely sure of its infallibility, is faith
author: Yevgeny Zamyatin

quote: In order that love be fully satisfied, It is necessary that It lower Itself and that It lower Itself to nothingness and transform this nothingness into fire.
author: Teresa of Ávila

quote: He who has not God in himself cannot feel His absence.
author: Simone Weil

quote: Commonly men will only be brave as their fathers were brave, or timid.
author: Henry David Thoreau

quote: We will experience the life we have the faith to experience.
author: Julia Cameron
reference: Faith and Will: Weathering the Storms in Our Spiritual Lives

quote: Ð’ÐµÑ€Ð° Ð² ÑÐµÐ±Ñ ÑÐ¿Ð¾ÑÐ¾Ð±Ð½Ð° Ñ‚Ð²Ð¾Ñ€Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ñ‚Ð°ÐºÐ¸Ðµ Ð¶Ðµ Ñ‡ÑƒÐ´ÐµÑÐ°, ÐºÐ°Ðº Ð²ÐµÑ€Ð° Ð² Ð“Ð¾ÑÐ¿Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ð‘Ð¾Ð³Ð°.
author: Honoré de Balzac

quote: The truth of our faith becomes a matter of ridicule among the infidels if any Catholic, not gifted with the necessary scientific learning, presents as dogma what scientific scrutiny shows to be false.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: It is certain that an atom of goodness on the path of faith is never lost.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: It is the test of a good religion whether you can joke about it.
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: Faith is a marvel, and yet no human being is excluded from it; for that in which all human life is united is passion, and faith is a passion.
author: Søren Kierkegaard

quote: Fe es aquello que nos permite creer en cosas que sabemos que no son ciertas.
author: Bram Stoker

quote: No coward soul is mine,No trembler in the world's storm-troubled sphere:I see heaven's glories shine,And faith shines equal, arming me from fear
author: Emily Brontë

quote: It was wrong to be so joyless, so desponding; I should have made God my friend, and to do His will the pleasure and the business of my life; but faith was weak, and passion was too strong.
author: Anne Brontë

quote: We act like pagans in a crisis--only one out of an entire crowd is daring enough to invest his faith in the character of God.
author: Oswald Chambers

quote: I shall not commit the grievous sin of losing faith in Man
author: Rabindranath Tagore

quote: Goodness is, so to speak, itself: badness is only spoiled goodness.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: Faith does not limit itself by the idea of a world, a universe, a necessity.
author: Ludwig Feuerbach

quote: ... God loved me not because I was lovable, but because it was His nature to do so.
author: Oswald Chambers

quote: It is now clear that faith is a singular pledge of paternal love, treasured up for the sons whom he has adopted.
author: John Calvin
reference: Institutes of the Christian Religion, 2 Vols

quote: It is necessary ... to yield to the storm, purchase a peace, and wait patiently for better times.
author: Alexandre Dumas

quote: I never swear, Monseigneur. I say Yes or No, and as I am a gentleman, I keep my word.
author: Alexandre Dumas

quote: As the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without deeds is dead.
author: Oswald Chambers

quote: I believe this not in the sense that it is part of my creed, but in the sense that it is one of my opinions. My religion would not be in ruins if this opinion were shown to be false.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: The Prayer that precedes all other prayer is, may the real me meet the real you.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: No tears in the writer, no tears in the reader. No surprise in the writer, no surprise in the reader.
author: Robert Frost

quote: If I, being what I am, can consider that I am in some sense a Christian, why should the different vices of those people in the next pew prove that their religion is mere hypocrisy and convention?
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: The perfect surrender and humiliation were undergone by Christ: perfect because He was God, surrender and humiliation because He was man.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: There is nothing to writing. All you do is sit down at a typewriter and bleed.
author: Ernest Hemingway

quote: Lock up your libraries if you like; but there is no gate, no lock, no bolt that you can set upon the freedom of my mind.
author: Virginia Woolf

quote: And by the way, everything in life is writable about if you have the outgoing guts to do it, and the imagination to improvise. The worst enemy to creativity is self-doubt.
author: Sylvia Plath
reference: The Unabridged Journals of Sylvia Plath

quote: The hard part about writing a novel is finishing it.
author: Ernest Hemingway

quote: Child, to say the very thing you really mean, the whole of it, nothing more or less or other than what you really mean; that's the whole art and joy of words.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: A writer only begins a book. A reader finishes it.
author: Samuel Johnson

quote: Get it down. Take chances. It may be bad, but it's the only way you can do anything good.
author: William Faulkner

quote: All words are pegs to hang ideas on.
author: Henry Ward Beecher

quote: Writers are really people who write books not because they are poor, but because they are dissatisfied with the books which they could buy but do not like.
author: Walter Benjamin

quote: Read over your compositions, and wherever you meet with a passage which you think is particularly fine, strike it out.
author: Samuel Johnson
reference: The Life of Samuel Johnson LL.D. Vol 2

quote: All good books are alike in that they are truer than if they really happened and after you are finished reading one you feel that it all happened to you and after which it all belongs to you.
author: Ernest Hemingway

quote: You never push a noun against a verb without trying to blow up something.
author: H.L. Mencken

quote: I can shake off everything as I write; my sorrows disappear, my courage is reborn.
author: Anne Frank

quote: Cut out all these exclamation points. An exclamation point is like laughing at your own joke.
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

quote: If I do not write to empty my mind, I go mad.
author: George Gordon Byron

quote: If the word doesn't exist, invent it; but first be sure it doesn't exist.
author: Charles Baudelaire

quote: It's harder to write in the third person but the advantage is you move around better.
author: Ernest Hemingway

quote: People do not deserve good writing, they are so pleased with bad.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: In a weak moment, I have written a book.
author: Margaret Mitchell

quote: Fiction is about everything human and we are made out of dust, and if you scorn getting yourself dusty, then you shouldn't try to write fiction. It's not a grand enough job for you.
author: Flannery O'Connor

quote: Our age not only does not have a very sharp eye for the almost imperceptible intrusions of grace, it no longer has much feeling for the nature of the violences which precede and follow them.
author: Flannery O'Connor

quote: A person who publishes a book willfully appears before the populace with his pants down. If it is a good book nothing can hurt him. If it is a bad book nothing can help him.
author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

quote: This tremendous world I have inside of me. How to free myself, and this world, without tearing myself to pieces. And rather tear myself to a thousand pieces than be buried with this world within me.
author: Franz Kafka

quote: I am irritated by my own writing. I am like a violinist whose ear is true, but whose fingers refuse to reproduce precisely the sound he hears within.
author: Gustave Flaubert

quote: Only those things are beautiful which are inspired by madness and written by reason.
author: André Gide

quote: The best way to become acquainted with a subject is to write about it.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote: Words - so innocent and powerless as they are, as standing in a dictionary, how potent for good and evil they become in the hands of one who knows how to combine them.
author: Nathaniel Hawthorne

quote: There is creative reading as well as creative writing.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Write what you know.
author: Mark Twain
reference: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer & Adventures of Huckleberry Finn

quote: No passion in the world is equal to the passion to alter someone else's draft.
author: H.G. Wells

quote: A writer is a world trapped in a person.
author: Victor Hugo

quote: I think all writing is a disease. You can't stop it.
author: William Carlos Williams

quote: When I write, I disturb. When I show a film, I disturb. When I exhibit my painting, I disturb, and I disturb if I don't. I have a knack for disturbing.
author: Jean Cocteau

quote: Fill your paper with the breathings of your heart.
author: William Wordsworth

quote: You can make anything by writing.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: But yield who will to their separation, My object in living is to uniteMy avocation and my vocationAs my two eyes make one in sight.

quote: You have power over your mind - not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.

quote: Do you want to know who you are? Don't ask. Act! Action will delineate and define you.

quote: A true writer is someone the gods have called to the task.

quote: I call him religious who understands the suffering of others.

quote: Aim at Heaven and you will get Earth 'thrown in': aim at Earth and you will get neither.

quote: â€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€Žâ€ŽThe mind of God is greater than all the minds of men, so let all men leave the gospel just as God has delivered it unto us.
author: Charles Haddon Spurgeon

quote: All the tales of miracles, with which the Old and New Testament are filled, are fit only for impostors to preach and fools to believe.

quote: My country is the world, and my religion is to do good.

quote: The gods, not out of mercy, have made me strong.

quote: the difference between the old and the new education being) in a word, the old was a kind of propagation - men transmitting manhood to men; the new is merely propaganda.

quote: Education is not the learning of facts, but the training of the mind to think

quote: The boy knew that escaping school was the surest sign of his election.

quote: I do not consider my deeds or my knowledge to be a great thing. The only fact is - and I can say this honestly - that I love learning and a solitary life.

quote: I have a pretty large experience of boys, and you're a bad set of fellows. Now mind!

quote: Knowledge itself is power
author: Francis Bacon

quote: People are islands,' she said. 'They don't really touch. However close they are, they're really quite separate. Even if they've been married for fifty years.

quote: She preferred imaginary heroes to real ones, because when tired of them, the former could be shut up in the tin kitchen till called for, and the latter were less manageable.
author: Louisa May Alcott

quote: There is a soul-jealousy that can be as frantic as any body-jealousy.

quote: The meeting of two personalities is like the contact of two chemical substances: if there is any reaction, both are transformed.

quote: I think you are wrong to want a heart. It makes most people unhappy. If you only knew it, you are in luck not to have a heart.

quote: You like every one; that is to say, you are indifferent to every one.

quote: A woman can become a man's friend only in the following stages - first an acquantaince, next a mistress, and only then a friend.

quote: In the best, the friendliest and simplest relations flattery or praise is necessary, just as grease is necessary to keep wheels turning.

quote: Why, you are a man of heart!"Sometimes," replied Phileas Fogg, quietly. "When I have the time.

quote: Never marry at all, Dorian. Men marry because they are tired, women, because they are curious: both are disappointed.

quote: [Marriage] happens as with cages: the birds without despair to get in, and those within despair of getting out.

quote: Most people think everybody feels about them much more violently than they actually do they think other people's opinions of them swing through great arcs of approval or disapproval.

quote: No people find each other more absurd than lovers

quote: I know I am but summer to your heart, and not the full four seasons of the year.

quote: The reason we all like to think so well of others is that we are all afraid for ourselves. The basis of optimism is sheer terror.

quote: Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.

quote: We walked to meet each other up at the time of our love and then we have been irresistibly drifting in different directions, and there's no altering that.

quote: If thou dost seek to have what thou dost hide,By self-example mayst thou be denied.

quote: I used to advertise my loyalty and I don't believe there is a single person I loved that I didn't eventually betray.

quote: He who wants a rose must respect her thorn.

quote: When a man has seen the woman whom he would have chosen if he had intended to marry speedily, his remaining a bachelor will usually depend on her resolution rather than on his.

quote: Second hand books are wild books, homeless books; they have come together in vast flocks of variegated feather, and have a charm which the domesticated volumes of the library lack.

quote: I shall keep my book on the table here, and read a little every morning as soon as I wake, for I know it will do me good, and help me through the day.
author: Louisa May Alcott

quote: Literature is the art of discovering something extraordinary about ordinary people, and saying with ordinary words something extraordinary.

quote: For books continue each other, in spite of our habit of judging them separately.
author: Virginia Woolf
reference: A Room of One's Own and Three Guineas

quote: Read not to contradict and confute, nor to believe and take for granted ...but to weigh and consider.

quote: Every face, every shop, bedroom window, public-house, and dark square is a picture feverishly turned--in search of what? It is the same with books. What do we seek through millions of pages?

quote: The books that influence the world are those that it has not read.

quote: Knowing I lov'd my books, he furnish'd me From mine own library with volumes that I prize above my dukedom.

quote: This will never be a civilized country until we expend more money for books than we do for chewing gum.

quote: As we expand our knowledge of good books, we shrink the circle of men whose company we appreciate.

quote: Before you sleep, read something that is exquisite, and worth remembering.

quote: She is too fond of books, and it has turned her brain
author: Louisa May Alcott

quote: In the highest civilization, the book is still the highest delight. He who has once known its satisfactions is provided with a resource against calamity.

quote: All that mankind has done, thought, gained, or been; it is lying as in magic preservation in the pages of books.

quote: My books are friends that never fai
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Some books are so familiar that reading them is like being home again.
author: Louisa May Alcott

quote: it is nice that nobody writes as they talk and that the printed language is different from the spoken otherwise you could not lose yourself in books and of course you do you completely do.
author: Gertrude Stein

quote: . . . finally, I couldn't imagine how I could live without books, and I stopped dreaming about marrying that Chinese prince. . . .

quote: Your goodness must have some edge to it -- else it is none.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
reference: Culture, Behavior, Beauty, Books, Art, Eloquence, Power, Wealth, Illusions

quote: We learn words by rote, but not their meaning; that must be paid for with our life-blood, and printed in the subtle fibres of our nerves.

quote: A library implies an act of faith which generations, still in darkness hid, sign in their night in witness of the
author: Victor Hugo

quote: Don't you ever mind," she asked suddenly, "not being rich enough to buy all the books you want?

quote: As you grow ready for it, somewhere or other you will find what is needful for you in a book.

quote: Many a man lives a burden to the Earth, but a good book is the precious life-blood of a master spirit, imbalmed and treasured up on purpose to a life beyond life.

quote: The books we read should be chosen with great care, that they may be, as an Egyptian king wrote over his library,'The medicines of the soul.

quote: Get books, sit yourself down anywhere, and go to reading them yourself.

quote: When I want to read a novel, I write one.

quote: Our experience is coloured through and through by books and plays and the cinema, and it takes patience and skill to disentangle the things we have really learned from life for ourselves.
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: I think we ought to read only the kind of books that wound and stab us. If the book weâ€™re reading doesnâ€™t wake us up with a blow on the head, what are we reading it for?
author: Franz Kafka
reference: Letters to Friends, Family, and Editors

quote: On no days of our childhood did we live so fully perhaps as those we thought we had left behind without living them, those that we spent with a favourite book.

quote: A book is a mirror: if an ape looks into it an apostle is hardly likely to look out.

quote: How many cities have revealed themselves to me in the marches I undertook in the pursuit of books!

quote: Those of us who are blamed when old for reading childish books were blamed when children for reading books too old for us.

quote: What are American dry-goods? asked the duchess, raising her large hands in wonder and accentuating the verb.American novels, answered Lord Henry.

reference: The Picture of Dorian Gray and Other Writings

quote: A book is good company. It is full of conversation without loquacity. It comes to your longing with full instruction, but pursues you never.

quote: What's the use trying to read Shakespeare, especially in one of those little paper editions whose pages get ruffled, or stuck together with sea-water?

quote: There are books showing men how to succeed in everything they are written by men who cannot even succeed in writing books.

quote: One sheds ones sickness in books- repeats and presents again ones emotions, to be master of them.

quote: Do you love tragedies and everything that breaks the heart?

quote: It is not all books that are as dull as their readers.

quote: Libraries can in general be too narrow or too wide for the soul.

quote: When I read a novel my imagination starts off at a gallop and leaves the narrator hidden in a cloud of dust I have to come jogging twenty miles back to the denouement.

quote: His reading suggested a man swimming in the sea among the wreckage of his ship, and trying to save his life by greedily clutching first at one spar and then at another.

quote: Even the names of the books gave me food for thought.

quote: Let this little book be thy friend, if, owing to fortune or through thine own fault, thou canst not find a dearer companion.

quote: No magic Rune is stranger than a Book. All that Mankind has done, thought, gained or been: it is lyingas in magic preservation in the pages of Books. They are the chosen possession of men.

quote: In the meantime, there is not an hour to lose. I am about to visit the public library.
author: Jules Verne
reference: Journey to the Center of the Earth

reference: An Epistle from Mr. Pope, to Dr. Arbuthnot.

quote: One bright day in the last week of February, I was walking in the park, enjoying the threefold luxury of solitude, a book, and pleasant weather.

quote: Let us not kid ourselves; let us remember that literature is of no use whatever, except in the very special case of somebody's wishing to become, of all things, a Professor of Literature.

quote: ...and he glanced at the backs of the books, with an awakened curiosity that went below the binding. No one who can read, ever looks at a book, even unopened on a shelf, like one who cannot.

quote: When a book and a head collide and a hollow sound is heard, must it always have come from the book?

quote: No days, perhaps, of all our childhood are ever so fully lived are those that we had regarded as not being lived at all: days spent wholly with a favourite book.

quote: When a goat likes a book, the whole book is gone,and the meaning has to go find an author again.- The Trouble With Reading

quote: There is a great deal of difference between an eager man who wants to read a book, and a tired man who wants a book to read.

quote: Of all the things which man can do or make here below, by far the most momentous, wonderful, and worthy are the things we call books.

quote: Naturally, since I myself am a writer, I do not wish the ordinary reader to read no modern books. But if he must read only the new or only the old, I would advise him to read the old.

quote: The clean book bill will be one of the most immoral measures ever adopted. It will throw American art back into the junk heap.

quote: This man's spiritual power has been precisely this, that he has distinguished between custom and creed. He has broken the conventions, but he has kept the commandments.
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: The sea is only the embodiment of asupernatural and wonderful existence.It is nothing but love and emotionit is the â€˜Living Infinite...
author: Jules Verne

quote: Woe to that seven months abortion who thinks to take advantage of the accidents of birth, and, mocking the call of duty, sneaks off to stare at a wall in China!
author: Aleister Crowley

quote: If I discover within myself a desire which no experience in this world can satisfy, the most probable explanation is that I was made for another world.

quote: I swear the earth shall surely be complete to him or her who shall be complete,The earth remains jagged and broken only to him or her who remains jagged and broken.

quote: Feel nothing, know nothing, do nothing, have nothing, give up all to God, and say utterly, 'Thy will be done.' We only dream this bondage. Wake up and let it go.

quote: ...your tranquil yes to the changing over into the formless void of the unlimited.

quote: The universe is not outside of you. Look inside yourself; everything that you want, you already are.
author: Jalaluddin Rumi

quote: I am all in a sea of wonders. I doubt; I fear; I think strange things, which I dare not confess to my own soul.

quote: Gratitude looks to the Past and love to the Present; fear, avarice, lust, and ambition look ahead.

quote: There's no better cure for the fear of taking after one's father, than not to know who he is.

quote: Fear is a vile thing, and is at the bottom of almost every wrong and hatred of the world.

quote: No one ever told me that grief felt so like fear.

quote: Move outside the tangle of fear-thinking. Live in silence.

quote: Even if she be not harmed, her heart may fail her in so much and so many horrors; and hereafter she may suffer--both in waking, from her nerves, and in sleep, from her dreams.

quote: How blessed are some people, whose lives have no fears, no dreads; to whom sleep is a blessing that comes nightly, and brings nothing but sweet dreams.

quote: Men are not afraid of things, but of how they view them.

quote: If you take too long in deciding what to do with your life, you'll find you've done it.

quote: The human mind is often, and I think it is for the most part, in a state neither of pain nor pleasure, which I call a state of indifference.

quote: He who fears he shall suffer, already suffers what he fears.

quote: If you are afraid of being lonely, don't try to be right.

quote: Keep your fears to yourself, but share your courage with others.

quote: Mastering others is strength. Mastering oneself makes you fearless.

quote: But the thought of being a lunatic did not greatly trouble him the horror was that he might also be wrong.

quote: Screw your courage to the sticking-place
author: William Shakespeare

quote: my imagination persisted in sticking horrors into the dark- so I stuck my imagination into the dark instead, and let it look out at me.

quote: Let fear once get possession of the soul, and it does not readily yield its place to another sentiment.Sebastopol by Leo Tolstoy
author: Leo Tolstoy

quote: There is a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at the will of others. My courage always rises at every attempt to intimidate me.

quote: Most people do not really want freedom, because freedom involves responsibility, and most people are frightened of responsibility.

quote: Secrets, silent, stony sit in the dark palaces of both our hearts: secrets weary of their tyranny: tyrants willing to be dethroned.

quote: It's all nonsense. It's only nonsense. I'm not afraid of the rain. I am not afraid of the rain. Oh, oh, God, I wish I wasn't.

author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Men know that women are an overmatch for them, and therefore they choose the weakest or the most ignorant. If they did not think so, they never could be afraid of women knowing as much as themselves.

quote: Only the unknown frightens men. But once a man has faced the unknown, that terror becomes the known.

quote: Where your fear is,there is your task.

quote: O all you host of heaven! O earth! What else?And shall I couple Hell?

quote: What lies before us? Horrible thoughts arise in my heart. If we had died before today we should have been happy.

quote: Nothing should be so greatly feared as empty fame.

quote: The truth Fear tells is not much better than her lies.

quote: The greatest thing in this world is not so much where we stand as in what direction we are moving.

quote: But we are strong, each in our purpose, and we are all more strong together.

quote: Each time we face our fear, we gain strength, courage, and confidence in the doing.

quote: Your purpose in life is to find your purpose and give your whole heart and soul to it
author: Gautama Buddha

quote: Cat: Where are you going?Alice: Which way should I go?Cat: That depends on where you are going.Alice: I donâ€™t know.Cat: Then it doesnâ€™t matter which way you go.
author: Lewis Carroll

quote: The truth is that you are afraid.''Afraid? I do not know all the words in the Parisian jargon, and I know not what you mean.
author: Alexandre Dumas
reference: The Son of Porthos: Or, the Death of Aramis

quote: The purpose of life is not to be happy. It is to be useful, to be honorable, to be compassionate, to have it make some difference that you have lived and lived well.

quote: There can be no disparity in marriage like unsuitability of mind and purpose.

quote: No small art is it to sleep: it is necessary for that purpose to keep awake all day.

quote: Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus. Our bodies are our gardens to the which our wills are gardeners.

quote: Watson. Come at once if convenient. If inconvenient, come all the same.

quote: True friends are always together in spirit. (Anne Shirley)
